learning_outcomes.description: Explain how scientific knowledge and progress is developed in biomedical science.
Identify and explain how the structure and function of the nervous system coordinate the body's response to internal and external stimuli.
Identify and explain how the anatomical structures of the heart and blood vessels relate to their physiological functions.
Identify and explain the relationships between the anatomical features of the respiratory system and its physiological functions.
Work and learn collaboratively in group settings, valuing and responding respectfully to diverse abilities, backgrounds, and perspectives.
Evaluate and reflect on your learning experiences throughout the course to identify strengths and areas for development in your understanding, learning strategies, and collaborative practice.

assessments.weighting: <dd>12% 2% per quiz - best 6 scores out of 8 quizzes available count towards 12% </dd>
assessments.task_description:
During each Teams Skills and Smart Skills Workshop, you will complete an online quiz through Blackboard. The best 6 scores from 8 quizzes available will count towards the 12% that these quizzes contribute to your overall grade for the BIOM1001.

Details of the quiz format and marking criteria will be communicated during the semester through Blackboard and by the Course Coordinators.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The exam will cover content related to Module 1, including lectures, prescribed readings, and workshop content. The exam will consist of multiple-choice and various interactive questions.

The exam will be a closed-book invigilated exam on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students must bring a laptop that meets the device requirements for Inspera to the exam. It is essential to verify before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library. The Library website, "Get familiar with Inspera," provides the latest information for students on using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard.

Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 3(23 Feb - 15 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 - Biomedical Practice [Suarez/Midwinter]

Module 1 will be delivered by Associate Professor Rodrigo Suarez and Professor Mark Midwinter via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. This module will introduce you to Biomedical Science broadly, while introducing key topics including levels of biological organisation, systems anatomy/physiology, homeostasis in health (and disease), data appraisal, critical thinking and problem-solving. You will explore and apply your knowledge of these core concepts in other modules throughout the semester in the context of specific body systems.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1 - Biomedical Practice [Suarez/Midwinter] Module 1 will be delivered by Associate Professor Rodrigo Suarez and Professor Mark Midwinter via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. You will explore and apply your knowledge of these core concepts in other modules throughout the semester in the context of specific body systems.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 10(23 Feb - 10 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Team Skills Workshops

Team Skills Workshops will involve process-oriented, collaborative learning activities completed in teams, and an in-class quiz. There are four Team Skills Workshops across the semester:

  • Week 1: Biomedical Practices Team Skills Workshop.
  • Week 4: Nervous System Team Skills Workshop
  • Week 8: Cardiovascular System Team Skills Workshop
  • Week 11: Respiratory System Team Skills Workshop

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Team Skills Workshops Team Skills Workshops will involve process-oriented, collaborative learning activities completed in teams, and an in-class quiz. learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 11(02 Mar - 17 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Smart Skills Workshops

Smart Skills Workshops will involve goal-oriented, collaborative learning activities completed in teams, and an in-class quiz. There are four Smart Skills Workshops across the semester:

  • Week 2: Biomedical Practices Smart Skills Workshop
  • Week 5: Nervous System Smart Skills Workshop
  • Week 9: Cardiovascular System Smart Skills Workshop
  • Week 12: Respiratory System Smart Skills Workshop

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 6(16 Mar - 05 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 - Nervous System [Coakley]

Module 2 will be delivered by Dr Sean Coakley via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. In this module, you will be introduced to the structure and function of the nervous system. This incredibly complex network of billions of neurons controls every aspect of the human condition. You will learn about the cells that make up the nervous system, how their structure is related to their function and how they send electrical signals throughout the body to control every conscious and unconscious action we take.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 2 - Nervous System [Coakley] Module 2 will be delivered by Dr Sean Coakley via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. In this module, you will be introduced to the structure and function of the nervous system. This incredibly complex network of billions of neurons controls every aspect of the human condition. You will learn about the cells that make up the nervous system, how their structure is related to their function and how they send electrical signals throughout the body to control every conscious and unconscious action we take.

learning_activities.topic:
Biomed Cohort Connections Week

Scheduled during the usual BIOM001 Lecture and Workshop times, this week of co-curricular activities will include fun and informative opportunities for you to engage with students in your cohort and across the Biomedical Science program, student societies, alumni, course teaching staff, and the wider biomed community at SBMS.


Learning outcomes: L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Biomed Cohort Connections Week Scheduled during the usual BIOM001 Lecture and Workshop times, this week of co-curricular activities will include fun and informative opportunities for you to engage with students in your cohort and across the Biomedical Science program, student societies, alumni, course teaching staff, and the wider biomed community at SBMS.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 8 To Week 10(20 Apr - 10 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 - Cardiovascular System [Thomas]

Module 3 will be delivered by Professor Wally Thomas via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. In this module you will explore the physiology and anatomy of the cardiovascular system and the remarkable pump, the heart, that propels blood through our vessels. You will be introduced to how cardiac muscle contracts, how blood pressure is controlled and explore the huge burden of cardiovascular disease on our healthcare system.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3 - Cardiovascular System [Thomas] Module 3 will be delivered by Professor Wally Thomas via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. You will be introduced to how cardiac muscle contracts, how blood pressure is controlled and explore the huge burden of cardiovascular disease on our healthcare system.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 11 To Week 13(11 May - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 4 - Respiratory System [Faber]

Module 4 will be delivered by Dr Luli Faber via 6 Lectures, one Team Skills Workshop, and one Smart Skills Workshop. In this module you will explore why we breathe, what happens if we don't and the important jobs of our incredible respiratory system.


Learning outcomes: L01, L04
